title: Man Utd handed Jesse Lingard boost ahead of Partizan clash – but David de Gea skips training
text:
Jesse Lingard returned to training ahead of Manchester United’s clash with Partizan (Picture: Reuters)

Jesse Lingard has returned to training ahead of Manchester United’s Europa League clash with Partizan, but there was no sign of David de Gea during Wednesday’s session.

A hamstring injury meant Lingard missed United’s last two Premier League matches against Newcastle and Liverpool, but the midfielder will travel with the rest of Ole Gunnar Solskjaer’s squad to Serbia.

Though De Gea managed 90 minutes versus Liverpool at the weekend after overcoming a groin problem he picked up on international duty, the goalkeeper skipped United’s latest training session.

Paul Pogba (foot), Luke Shaw (thigh), Diogo Dalot (groin/hip), Axel Tuanzebe (hip) and Nemanja Matic (muscle) were also absent at Carrington and are unavailable for Thursday evening’s tie.

United's travelling squad for Partizan clash Sergio Romero, Lee Grant, Matej Kovar; Phil Jones, Ethan Laird, Victor Lindelof, Harry Maguire, Marcos Rojo, Aaron Wan-Bissaka, Brandon Williams; Fred, James Garner, Daniel James, Jesse Lingard, Scott McTominay, Juan Mata, Andreas Pereira; Mason Greenwood, Anthony Martial, Marcus Rashford.

De Gea skipped United’s training session on Wednesday (Picture: PA)

According to The Sun, Tuanzebe will return from his hip injury to face Norwich on Sunday.

The young defender pulled up in warm-up ahead of United’s 1-1 draw with Liverpool and was replaced by Marcos Rojo in Solskjaer’s starting XI.

The Red Devils have picked up four points from their opening two games in Group L and victory in Belgrade would make them frontrunners to progress through to the next round.

Solskjaer is expected to field several youngsters at Partizan Stadium, with the likes of Ethan Laird, James Garner and Brandon Williams in line to feature.

Solskjaer’s side have picked up four points in Group L (Picture: Getty)

Solskjaer hinted he could stick with a three-man defence after switching to the formation for United’s draw with Liverpool at Old Trafford.

‘It can develop into something because we’ve got the players to play with three at the back. It allows more width in the team than we’ve had,’ the Norwegian said.

‘Of course, it’s a risk when you play with three at the back against their front three, which is a great front three. But it’s a risk we had to take.

‘We did it to create chances for ourselves. I thought the goal was the perfect example of how we wanted the game to pan out.’

Solskjaer added: ‘We’re better when we attack quickly – no dilly-dallying on the ball. Play the ball forward – it doesn’t have to be a counter attack.

‘I spoke about it before the game: take more risks, be braver. It doesn’t matter if you lose the ball up there because you can win it back.

‘In the Champions League final, Liverpool got a penalty after 40 seconds from hooking the ball in behind [off a player’s arm].

‘It’s about playing the right type of football and playing direct helped us.’
